• Store the seeds in 700 gauge polythene bag for long term storage (more than 15 months) with a seed moisture content less than $8 \%$ .

instruction: According to the section "Storage", what information is provided? Quote it.
response:
Store the seeds in gunny or cloth bags for short term storage (8 - 9 months) with a seed moisture content of $10 \mathrm { ~ - ~ } 1 2 \mathrm { ~ \% ~ }$ .
• Store the seeds in polylined gunny bag for medium term storage (12 - 15 months) with a seed moisture content of $8 \%$ .
• Store the seeds in 700 gauge polythene bag for long term storage (more than 15 months) with a seed moisture content less than $8 \%$ .

instruction: From the guide section "2. FORMING RAISED BED", extract the content verbatim.
response:
i. Mark units of 6 plots each of size $3 \mathsf { m } \times 1 . 5 \mathsf { m }$ . Provide 30 cm space between plots for irrigation.   
ii. Excavate the soil from the interspace and all around to a depth of ${ 1 5 } \thinspace { \mathsf { c m } }$ to form channels and spread the soil removed from the channels on the bed and level.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "3. PRE-TREATMENT OF THE SEEDS WITH FUNGICIDES" from the guide.
response:
i. Seed treatment with Azospirillum may be done @ 3 packets/ha $( 6 0 0 \mathrm { g / h a ) }$ and 3 packets $( 6 0 0 \mathrm { g / h a } )$ of Phosphobacteria or 6 packets of Azophos $( 1 2 0 0 ~ \mathrm { g / h a } )$ .   
ii. Mix the seeds in a polythene bag to ensure a uniform coating of seeds with Thiram 4 g/ kg or Captan $4 ~ \mathrm { g } / \ k \mathrm { g }$ or Carbendazim $2 ~ \mathrm { g } / \ k \mathrm { g }$ of seeds.

instruction: What does the guide state under the heading "3. PRE-TREATMENT OF THE SEEDS WITH FUNGICIDES"? Quote the text.
response:

ii. Mix the seeds in a polythene bag to ensure a uniform coating of seeds with Thiram 4 g/ kg or Captan $4 ~ \mathrm { g } / \ k \mathrm { g }$ or Carbendazim $2 ~ \mathrm { g } / \ k \mathrm { g }$ of seeds.

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "4. SOWING AND COVERING THE SEEDS" in the guide.
response:
i. Make shallow rills not deeper than one cm on the beds by passing the fingers vertically over them.

ii. Broadcast 5 kg of treated hand seeds evenly on the beds.   
iii. Cover the seeds by the hand lightly over the soil.   
iv. Sprinkle $5 0 0 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ of powdered FYM over the beds evenly to cover the seeds which are exposed and compact the surface lightly.

NOTE: Do not sow the seeds deep as germination will be adversely affected.

instruction: From the guide section "5. WATER MANAGEMENT", extract the content verbatim.
response:
i. Provide one inlet to each nursery unit.   
ii. Allow water to enter so as to cover all the channels around the bed. Allow the water in the channel to raise till the raised beds are fully wet and then cut off water.   
iii. Adjust the frequency of irrigation according to the soil type.

No. of irrigations RED SOILS HEAVY SOILS 1st Immediately after sowing Immediately after sowing 2nd 3rd day after sowing 4th day after sowing $3 ^ { \mathsf { r d } }$ 7th day after sowing 9th day after sowing $4 ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ $1 2 ^ { \mathfrak { t h } }$ day after sowing 16th day after sowing 5th $1 7 ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ day after sowing

NOTE:

1. One irrigation is given on the 3rd day in the case of red soil to soften the hard crust formed on the soil surface and also to facilitate seedlings to emerge out.

2. Do not allow cracks to develop in the nursery bed by properly adjusting the quantity of irrigation water.

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "1. TRANSPLANTING THE SEEDLINGS" in the guide.
response:
i. Let water into the bed, level the bed, if it is not levelled.   
ii. Plant 2 seedlings per hill.   
iii. Plant the seedlings at a depth of $3 \mathsf { c m }$ .   
iv. Plant 18 to 20 days old seedlings.   
v. Adopt a spacing of $3 0 { \times } 1 0 ~ \mathsf { c m }$ for planting.   
vi. Adopt $2 2 . 5 \times 1 0$ cm spacing for direct sowing.   
vii. Root dipping with Azospirillum: Prepare slurry with 5 packets $( 1 0 0 0 \ g / \mathsf { h a } )$ of Azospirillum and 5 packets $( 1 0 0 0 \mathrm { g / h a } )$ of Phosphobacteria or 10 packets of Azophos $( 2 0 0 0 \ g / \mathsf { h a } )$ in 40 litres of water and dip the root portion of the seedlings in the solution for 15-30 minutes and transplant.

instruction: From the guide section "2. WEED MANAGEMENT", extract the content verbatim.
response:
i. Apply PE Oxyfluorfen $@ 0 . 0 5 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ /ha on 3 DAS using Backpack Knapsack/Rocker sprayer fitted with flat fan type of nozzle with 500 litre of water/ha followed by one hand weeding on 20 DAS.   
ii. Apply the herbicides when there is sufficient moisture in the soil or irrigate immediately after application of herbicide.   
iii. If pre-emergence herbicide is not applied, hand weed twice on ${ 1 0 } ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ and $2 0 ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ DAT.   
iv. For rainfed direct seeded crop, apply post emergence herbicide; 2,4-DEE or 2,4-D Na salt at $0 . 5 ~ \mathsf { k g } / \mathsf { h a }$ on 10 DAS depending on the moisture availability.

3. HOEING AND HAND WEEDING

i. Hoe and hand weed on the $1 5 ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ day of planting in light soils and $1 7 ^ { \mathfrak { t h } }$ day of planting in heavy soils and subsequently on ${ 3 0 } ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ and $3 2 ^ { \mathsf { n d } }$ days, respectively.

ii. Allow the weeds to dry for 2 or 3 days after hand weeding before giving irrigation. NOTE: Do not adopt hoeing and hand weeding if herbicide is applied.

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "1. DECIDE WHEN TO HARVEST" in the guide.
response:
i. Ragi crop does not mature uniformly and hence the harvest is to be taken up in

two stages. ii. When the earhead on the main shoot and $50 \%$ of the earheads on the crop turn brown, the crop is ready for the first harvest.

instruction: From the guide section "Second Harvest", extract the content verbatim.
response:
i. Seven days after the first harvest, cut all the earheads including the green ones.   
ii. Cure the grains to obtain maturity by heaping the harvested earheads in shade for one day without drying, so that the humidity and temperature increase and the grains get cured.   
iii. Dry, thresh and clean the grains by winnowing and store the grains in gunnies.

instruction: What does the guide state under the heading "Second Harvest"? Quote the text.
response:
i. Seven days after the first harvest, cut all the earheads including the green ones.
ii. Cure the grains to obtain maturity by heaping the harvested earheads in shade for one day without drying, so that the humidity and temperature increase and the grains get cured.
iii. Dry, thresh and clean the grains by winnowing and store the grains in gunnies.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "Special problems" from the guide.
response:
i. Root Aphids: Mix Dimethoate $3 ~ \mathsf { m l }$ in one litre of water and drench the rhizosphere of the infested and surrounding plants with the insecticidal solution.   
ii. Rainfed ragi: Azospirillum mixed with FYM and applied to field saves the cost of nitrogen by $50 \%$ with a comparable yield obtained with $4 0 \mathrm { k g } \mathsf { N } / \mathsf { h a }$ .   
iii. Management of aged seedlings of ragi under rainfed conditions: When planting ragi seedlings beyond 21 days, increase the number of seedlings to 3/hill and increase N level by $2 5 \%$ to minimise yield loss.   
iv. Apply VAM culture (Glomus fasciculatum) at $\scriptstyle 1 0 0 \ { \mathrm { g } } / { \mathrm { m } } ^ { 2 }$ in the nursery and also treat with Azospirillum and Phosphobacterium as seed treatment, seedling dip and field application to reduce the reniform nematode population in ragi.

RAGI : RAINFED

ii. Rainfed ragi: Azospirillum mixed with FYM and applied to field saves the cost of nitrogen by $50 \%$ with a comparable yield obtained with $4 0 \mathrm { k g } \mathsf { N } / \mathsf { h a }$ .

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "Season" in the guide.
response:
Finger millet is grown in different seasons in different parts of the country. As a rainfed crop, it

is normally sown in June- July in Tamil Nadu. It also grown in winter season (rabi) by planting in September – October in Tamil Nadu and as a summer irrigated crop by planting January – February.

instruction: From the guide section "Seed rate and planting", extract the content verbatim.
response:
A plant population of 4 – 5 lakhs per ha is optimum for getting higher yields and higher or lower population than the optimum will reduce the yield. Line sowing is ideal and seed drills giving spacing of $2 2 . 5 - 3 0 ~ \mathsf { c m }$ between rows should be used. Finger millet seeds are very small (400 seeds/g) and the recommended seed rate is $1 0 ~ \mathsf { k g / h a }$ . Therefore, even when seed drill is used thinning within the row leaving a spacing of $7 . 5 - 1 0 ~ \mathsf { c m }$ between plants, must be followed.

Sowing by seed-cum-fertilizer drill is advantageous for line sowing besides efficient utilization of applied nutrients.

Maintenance of optimum plant population is an important prerequisite for getting higher yield under rainfed conditions. Poor germination, often, is the result of inadequate moisture after sowing in low rainfall areas. Under these conditions, the adoption of a simple technique like seed hardening will not only improve germination and subsequent plant stand but also impart early seedling vigour and tolerance to drought.

The procedure of seed hardening technique is as follows.

1. Sole seeds in water for 6 hours. Use one litre water for every kg seed for soaking.   
2. Drain the water and keep the seeds in wet cloth bag tightly tied for two days.   
3. At this stage, the seeds will show initial signs of germination.   
4. Remove seeds from the wet cloth bag and dry them in shade on a dry cloth for 2 days.   
5. Use the above hardened seeds for sowing.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "Procedures for inoculating seeds with biofertilizers" from the guide.
response:
1. Bio-fertilizer culture specific to the crop is to be used $@$ 25 g per kg of seed.   
2. Sticker solution is necessary for effective seed inoculation. This can be prepared by dissolving $2 5 ~ \mathsf { g }$ jaggery or sugar in ${ 2 5 0 } ~ \mathrm { m l }$ water and boiling for 5 minutes. The solution thus prepared is cooled.   
3. Smear the seeds well using the required quantity of sticker solution. Then add culture to the seeds and mix thoroughly so as to get a fine coating of culture on the seed.   
4. The culture-coated seeds is to be dried well in shade to avoid clumping of seeds.   
5. Use the inoculated seeds for sowing.

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "Weed control" in the guide.
response:
i. In line sown crop 2-3 inter-cultivations are necessary. In assured rainfall and irrigated areas spraying 2,4-D sodium salt $@$ 0.75 kg.a.i./ha as post-emergent spray on 20-25 days after sowing effectively controls weeds.   
ii. Apply, Isoproturon $\textcircled { \alpha } \ 0 . 5 \ \mathsf { a . i / h a }$ as pre-emergence on 3 DAS is also effective in control of weeds. In broadcast crop two effective hand weedings will minimize weeds as inter cultivations is not possible.   
iii. For direct sown rainfed ragi post-emergence application of 2, 4 D Na salt (or) EE formulation at $0 . 5 ~ \mathsf { k g } \mathsf { h a } ^ { - 1 }$ applied on 10 days after sowing and at $0 . 7 5 ~ { \mathsf { k g } } ~ { \mathsf { h a } } ^ { - 1 }$ applied on 15 days after sowing will give effective weed control as well as higher grain yield.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "Pre-sowing seed treatment" from the guide.
response:
Soak the seeds in $0 . 5 \ \% \ C a C l _ { 2 }$ for $^ { 6 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ at 1:1 ratio and dry back the seeds to original seed moisture content $( 8 - 9 \% )$ under shade. This can be adapted both for the garden and dry land ecosystem.   
Treat the graded seed with carbendazim $\textcircled { \alpha } 2 \mathrm { \bf g } / \mathrm { \bf k g }$ of seed.

instruction: According to the section "Pre-sowing seed treatment", what information is provided? Quote it.
response:
Soak the seeds in $0 . 5 \ \% \ C a C l _ { 2 }$ for $^ { 6 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ at 1:1 ratio and dry back the seeds to original seed moisture content $( 8 - 9 \% )$ under shade. This can be adapted both for the garden and dry land ecosystem.
Treat the graded seed with carbendazim $\textcircled { \alpha } 2 \mathrm { \bf g } / \mathrm { \bf k g }$ of seed.

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "Threshing" in the guide.
response:
Dry the earheads until the seed moisture content is reduced to $15 \%$ and seeds are separated manually by threshing with pliable bamboo stick or machine thresher. Pre-clean the threshed seeds before sun drying.   
Dry the seeds to $12 \%$ moisture content before grading.

instruction: From the guide section "Storage", extract the content verbatim.
response:
• Store the seeds in gunny or cloth bags for short term storage (8 - 9 months) with a seed moisture content of 10 to $12 \%$ .   
• Store the seeds in polylined gunny bag for medium term storage (12 - 15 months) with a seed moisture content of 8 to $9 \%$ .   
• Store the seeds in 700 gauge polythene bag for long term storage (more than 15 months) with a seed moisture content less than $8 \%$ .

instruction: From the guide section "3. FORMING RIDGES AND FURROWS OR BEDS", extract the content verbatim.
response:
Form ridges and furrows providing sufficient irrigation channels. The ridges should

be $6 \mathsf { m }$ long and 60 cm apart.   
If ridges and furrows are not made, form beds of size $1 0 ~ \mathsf { m } ^ { 2 }$ or $2 0 ~ \mathsf { m } ^ { 2 }$ depending on the availability of water.   
Use a bund former or ridge plough to economise cost of production.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "4. APPLICATION OF FERTILIZERS" from the guide.
response:
i. Soil test crop response based integrated plant nutrition system (STCR- IPNS) I If soil test recommendation is not available adopt a blanket recommendation of $1 3 5 { : 6 2 . 5 { : 5 0 } \mathsf { K g } } / { \mathsf { N P K } \mathsf { h a } ^ { - 1 } }$ for varieties and $2 5 0 { : } 7 5 { : } 7 5 \mathrm { ~ k g \ N P K \ h a } ^ { - 1 }$ for hybrid maize   
ii. Apply quarter of the dose of N; full dose of ${ \sf P } _ { 2 } { \sf O } _ { 5 }$ and ${ \sf K } _ { 2 } 0$ basally before sowing.   
iii. In the case of ridge planted crop, open a furrow 6 cm deep on the side of the ridge, at two thirds the distance from the top of the ridge.   
iv. Apply the fertilizer mixture along the furrows evenly and cover to a depth of 4 cm with soil.   
v. If bed system of planting is followed, open furrows 6 cm deep at a distance of 60 cm apart.   
vi. Place the fertilizer mixture along the furrows evenly and cover to a depth of 4 cm with soil.

Soil test crop response based integrated plant nutrition system (STCR- IPNS) recommendation may be adopted for prescribing fertilizer doses for specified yield targets. (ready reckoners are furnished )

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "5. APPLICATION OF MICRONUTRIENT" from the guide.
response:
i. $1 2 . 5 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ of micronutrient mixture formulated by the Department of Agriculture, Tamil Nadu, mixed with sand to make a total quantity of $5 0 \ \mathsf { k g / h a }$ is to be applied. (or)   
ii. Apply TNAU MN mixture $\textcircled { \alpha } 3 0 \mathrm { ~ } \mathrm { k g / h a }$ as enriched FYM (Prepare enriched FYM at 1:10 ratio MN mixture and FYM; mix at friable moisture and incubate for one month in shade.   
iii. Apply zinc sulphate $\textcircled { \alpha } 3 7 . 5 ~ \mathsf { k g } ~ \mathsf { h a } ^ { - 1 }$ for hybrid maize and $2 5 ~ \mathsf { k g } \mathsf { h } \mathsf { a } ^ { - 1 }$ for varieties can be followed in Zn deficient soils.   
iv. Apply $5 0 \mathrm { \ k g \ F e S O _ { 4 } } + 1 2 . 5 \mathrm { \ t F Y M \ h a } ^ { - 1 }$ along with $4 0 \ k g \leq$ as elemental sulphur for calcareous soils. Apply the mixture over the furrows and two thirds in the top of ridges, if ridge planting is followed. If bed system of sowing is followed, apply the micronutrient mixture over the beds.   
v. Apply $4 0 \ \mathsf { k g } \ \mathsf { S } .$ , $1 0 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ borax and $5 0 ~ { \mathsf { k g } } ~ { \mathsf { F e S O } } _ { 4 } + 1 2 . 5 ~ { \mathsf { t } }$ FYM for specific respective nutrient deficiency in soils.   
vi. For zinc and iron deficiencies in plants foliar spraying $0 . 5 \%$ $Z _ { \mathsf { n S O } _ { 4 } , }$ $1 \% \ F e S O _ { 4 } +$ $0 . 1 \%$ citric acid thrice on 30, 40 and 50 days after sowing can be followed.

instruction: What does the guide state under the heading "5. APPLICATION OF MICRONUTRIENT"? Quote the text.
response:
i. $1 2 . 5 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ of micronutrient mixture formulated by the Department of Agriculture, Tamil Nadu, mixed with sand to make a total quantity of $5 0 \ \mathsf { k g / h a }$ is to be applied. (or)
ii. Apply TNAU MN mixture $\textcircled { \alpha } 3 0 \mathrm { ~ } \mathrm { k g / h a }$ as enriched FYM (Prepare enriched FYM at 1:10 ratio MN mixture and FYM; mix at friable moisture and incubate for one month in shade.
iii. Apply zinc sulphate $\textcircled { \alpha } 3 7 . 5 ~ \mathsf { k g } ~ \mathsf { h a } ^ { - 1 }$ for hybrid maize and $2 5 ~ \mathsf { k g } \mathsf { h } \mathsf { a } ^ { - 1 }$ for varieties can be followed in Zn deficient soils.
iv. Apply $5 0 \mathrm { \ k g \ F e S O _ { 4 } } + 1 2 . 5 \mathrm { \ t F Y M \ h a } ^ { - 1 }$ along with $4 0 \ k g \leq$ as elemental sulphur for calcareous soils. Apply the mixture over the furrows and two thirds in the top of ridges, if ridge planting is followed. If bed system of sowing is followed, apply the micronutrient mixture over the beds.
v. Apply $4 0 \ \mathsf { k g } \ \mathsf { S } .$ , $1 0 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ borax and $5 0 ~ { \mathsf { k g } } ~ { \mathsf { F e S O } } _ { 4 } + 1 2 . 5 ~ { \mathsf { t } }$ FYM for specific respective nutrient deficiency in soils.
vi. For zinc and iron deficiencies in plants foliar spraying $0 . 5 \%$ $Z _ { \mathsf { n S O } _ { 4 } , }$ $1 \% \ F e S O _ { 4 } +$ $0 . 1 \%$ citric acid thrice on 30, 40 and 50 days after sowing can be followed.

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "7. SPACING" in the guide.
response:
Adopt a spacing of $2 5 \ \mathsf { c m }$ between plants in the rows which are 60 cm apart.

Population : For varieties and hybrids 6 – 7 plants / sq. m. and For baby corn, 8 – 9 plants / sq. m.

8. SEED TREATMENT

Step 1: Use pelleted seeds with insecticides (treat one $\mathsf { k g }$ of seeds with Chlorpyriphos 20EC or Monocrotophos 36 WSC or Phosalone 35 EC $@$ $\emptyset 4 \ : \mathrm { m l } + 0 . 5$ gram gum in ${ 2 0 } \mathsf { m } { 1 }$ of water) for the control of stem borer or seed treatment with imidacloprid 70 WS 10 g/kg of seeds.

Step 2: Seed treatment with Metalaxyl or Thiram $\textcircled { \alpha } \ 2 \ \& / \kappa g$ of seed for the control of downy mildew and crazy top

Step 3: Seeds treated with fungicides may be treated with three packets $( 6 0 0 ~ \mathrm { g / h a } )$ of Azospirillum before sowing.

9. SOWING

i. Dibble the seeds at a depth of 4 cm along the furrow in which fertilizers are placed and cover with soil.   
ii. Put one seed per hole if the germination is assured otherwise put two seeds per hole

10. WEED MANAGEMENT

i. Apply Atrazine $\textcircled { \ ; } ~ 0 . 5 0 ~ - ~ 0 . 7 5 ~ \mathrm { ~ k g / h a }$ as pre-emergence on 3-5 DAS using Backpack/ Knapsack/ Rocker sprayer fitted with a flat fan nozzle using 500 litres of water/ha followed by one hand weeding on 30-35 DAS. (or)   
ii. Apply Atrazine $\textcircled { \alpha } 0 . 5 0 ~ \mathrm { { k g / h a } }$ as pre-emergence on 3-5 DAS followed by 2,4-D $@$ $1 \ k g / \mathsf { h a }$ on 20-25 DAS, using Backpack/Knapsack/Rocker sprayer fitted with a flat fan nozzle using 500 litres of water/ha.   
iii. In line sown crop, apply PE Atrazine $\textcircled { \omega } \ 0 . 5 0 \ \mathrm { k g / h a }$ on 3-5 DAS followed by Twin Wheel hoe weeder weeding on 30-35 DAS.   
iv. Apply herbicide when there is sufficient moisture in the soil.   
v. Do not disturb the soil after herbicide application.   
vi. If pulse crop is to be raised as intercrop, do not use Atrazine. Spray Pendimethalin $\textcircled { \alpha } 0 . 7 5 ~ \mathrm { { \textk g / h a } }$ as pre emergence on 3-5 DAS.

instruction: Extract only the list items under "7. SPACING" from the guide.
response:
8. SEED TREATMENT
9. SOWING
10. WEED MANAGEMENT

instruction: From the guide section "11. THINNING AND GAP FILLING", extract the content verbatim.
response:
i. If two seeds were sown, leave only one healthy and vigorous seedling per hole and remove the other on the 12-15 days after sowing.   
ii. Where seedlings have not germinated, dibble presoaked seeds at the rate of 2 seeds per hole and immediately irrigate.

instruction: What does the guide state under the heading "11. THINNING AND GAP FILLING"? Quote the text.
response:
i. If two seeds were sown, leave only one healthy and vigorous seedling per hole and remove the other on the 12-15 days after sowing.
ii. Where seedlings have not germinated, dibble presoaked seeds at the rate of 2 seeds per hole and immediately irrigate.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "12. HOEING, HAND-WEEDING AND EARTHING UP" from the guide.
response:
i. Hoe and hand-weed on the 30th day of sowing. ii. Earth up and form new ridges so that the plants come directly on the top of the ridges. This will provide additional anchorage to the plants.

13. TOP DRESSING WITH NITROGEN

i. Place half of the dose of N on the $2 5 ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ day of sowing along the furrows evenly and cover it with soil. ii. Place the remaining quarter of N on the $4 5 ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ day of sowing

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "14. WATER MANAGEMENT" in the guide.
response:
Maize crop is sensitive to both moisture stress and excessive moisture, hence regulate irrigation according to the requirement. Ensure optimum moisture availability during the most critical phase (45 to 65 days after sowing); otherwise yield will be reduced by a considerable extent. Regulate irrigation according to the following growth phase of the crop. instruction: From the guide section "DRIP IRRIGATION TO MAIZE", extract the content verbatim.
response:
Irrigation once in 2 days   
Irrigation based on climatological approach Irrigation volume:   
$= ( { \mathsf { P e } } \times { \mathsf { K p } } \times { \mathsf { K c } } \times { \mathsf { A } } \times { \mathsf { W p } } ) - { \mathsf { R e } }$

Pe – Pan evaporation rate (mm/day) Kp – Pan co-efficient (0.75 to 0.80) Kc – Crop co-efficient (0.4 – Vegetative stage; 0.75 – Flowering stage; 1.05 – Grain formation stage) A – Area $( 7 5 \times 3 0 ~ \mathsf { c m } )$ (id:) Wp – Wetted percentage $80 \%$ for maize) Re – Effective rainfall (mm)

Irrigation duration Water requirement per plant once in 2 days

No. of dripper / plant x Discharge rate (lph)

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "HARVESTING STAGE OF HARVEST" in the guide.
response:
Observe the following symptoms, taking into consideration the average duration of the crop.

i. The sheath covering the cob will turn yellow and dry at maturity.   
ii. The seeds become fairly hard and dry. At this stage the crop is ready for harvest.

instruction: From the guide section "THRESHING THE COBS", extract the content verbatim.
response:
i. Dry the cobs under the sun till the grains are dry.   
ii. Use mechanical threshers or by running the tractor over dried cobs to separate the grains from the shank.   
iii. Clean the seeds by winnowing   
iv. Collect and store the dry grains in gunnies.

instruction: What does the guide state under the heading "THRESHING THE COBS"? Quote the text.
response:
i. Dry the cobs under the sun till the grains are dry.
ii. Use mechanical threshers or by running the tractor over dried cobs to separate the grains from the shank.
iii. Clean the seeds by winnowing
iv. Collect and store the dry grains in gunnies.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "3. APPLICATION OF FERTILIZER" from the guide.
response:
i. Apply NPK as per soil test recommendation as far as possible. If soil test recommendation is not available, adopt a blanket recommendation of $6 0 : 3 0 :$ 30 NPK kg/ha for Alfisols and $4 0 : 2 0 : 0 \mathsf { N P K } \mathsf { k g / h a }$ for Vertisols.   
ii. Apply half of N and full dose of $\mathsf { P } _ { 2 } \mathrm { ~ O ~ } _ { 5 }$ and ${ \sf K } _ { 2 }$ O with enriched FYM as basal along with Azospirillum (10 packets/ha).   
iii. Top dress remaining half of N at tasseling. Soil test crop response based integrated plant nutrition system (STCR- IPNS) recommendation may be adopted for prescribing fertilizer doses for specified yieldtargets. (ready reckoners are furnished )

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "8. CROPPING SYSTEMS" from the guide.
response:
i. Intercropping system of maize $^ +$ cowpea or maize $^ +$ blackgram is recommended for higher net returns in the red lateritic soils of Southern districts.   
ii. For Vertisols of Southern district, maize $^ +$ redgram intercropping systems is ideal.

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "Storage" in the guide.
response:
• Store the seeds in gunny or cloth bags for short term storage (8 - 9 months) with a seed moisture content of 10 to $12 \%$ .   
• Store the seeds in polylined gunny bag for medium term storage (12 - 15 months) with a seed moisture content of $8 \%$ .   
• Store the seeds in 700 gauge polythene bag for long term storage (more than 15 months) with a seed moisture content less than $8 \%$ .

instruction: From the guide section "8. WATER MANAGEMENT", extract the content verbatim.
response:
The crop requires 4 - 6 irrigations depending on the soil type and rainfall. Wheat crop requires minimum of 5 irrigations at the following critical stages.

$| =$ Immediately after sowing   
$| | =$ Crown root intiation : 15-20 DAS III $\equiv _ { - }$ Active tillering stage : 35-40 DAS   
$\mathsf { N } =$ Flowering stage : 50-55 DAS   
$\lor =$ Grain filling stage : 70-75 DAS

Crown root initiation and flowering are the most critical stages. Water stagnation should be avoided at the time of germination.

Highly susceptible to frost at the time of flowering, hardy, widely adaptable, and drought resistant. It has low tolerance of soil salinity and waterlogging.

instruction: From the guide section "3. TREATMENT OF THE SEEDS WITH BIOFERTILIZER", extract the content verbatim.
response:
a) Fungicide (or) bio control agents treated seeds should be again treated with bacterial culture after 24 hours. Treat the seeds required for sowing 1 ha with $2 0 0 { \mathsf { g } }$ each of Rhizobial culture CPR6 / CPR 9, phosphobacteria and PGPR (Pseudomonas sp.) using rice gruel, shade dry it before sowing. (or) Treat one hectare of seeds with $2 5 ~ \mathsf { g }$ each of powder formulation of Rhizobium and AM fungi using binder (polymer), shade dry before sowing.   
b) If seed treatment is not carried out, apply 2 kg each Rhizobial culture, Phosphobacteria and PGPR (Pseudomonas sp.) with $2 5 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ of FYM and $2 5 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ of sand, mix uniformly before sowing.

instruction: From the guide section "6. WEED MANAGEMENT", extract the content verbatim.
response:
i) Pre emergence application of Pendimethalin $0 . 7 5 ~ \mathrm { { k g / h a } }$ (2.5 litres/ha) on 3 DAS mixed with 500 litres of water using Backpack/Knapsack/Rocker sprayer using flat fan deflector type of nozzle. Then irrigate the field. Following this, one hand weeding may be given on 30-35 DAS   
ii) If herbicide is not given, give two hand weedings on 20 and 35 DAS.   
iii) In case of labour problem, apply Pendimethalin $0 . 7 5 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ (2.5 lit/ha) on 3 DAS followed by early post emergence application of Imazethapyr $@ 6 0 ~ \mathsfit { g }$ ai/ha on 15 DAE of weeds (2 - 3 leaves stage of weeds) and quizalofop ethyl $\textcircled { \alpha } 5 0 \ g \mathsf { a i } / \mathsf { h a }$ on 20 DAE of weeds (2 - 3 leaves of weeds) are recommended for controlling broad leaved and grassy weeds, respectively. If both the weeds are present, tank mix application of Imazethapyr $@ 6 0 \textrm { g }$ ai/ha and quizalofop ethyl $@ 5 0 \{ $ ai/ha at 15 - 20 days after emergence of weeds (2 - 3 leaves stage of weeds) is recommended. Apply PE Pendimethalin $30 \%$ EC $^ +$ Imazethapyr $2 \%$ EC (Valor $32 \%$ EC; Readymix herbicide) $@ 1 , 0 \mathsf { k g }$ a.i. ha-1 at 3 DAS.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "8. FOLIAR APPLICATION" from the guide.
response:
a) Foliar spray of NAA $4 0 \ : \mathrm { m g / l }$ once at pre-flowering and another at 15 days thereafter   
b) Foliar spray of DAP $2 0 ~ \mathsf { g } / |$ or urea $2 0 \ \mathsf { g } / \mathsf { I }$ once at flowering and another at 15 days there after   
c) Foliar spray of salicylic and $1 0 0 \mathsf { m } \mathsf { g } _ { \mathsf { \Lambda } }$ /litre once at preflowering and another at 15 days there after

9. HARVESTING THE CROP

1) Harvest the whole plants when $80 \%$ of the pods mature.   
2) Heap for 2 – 3 days   
3) Dry and process.

10. INTER-CROPPING

a) Raise one row of long duration redgram varieties as inter crop for every six rows of groundnut (6:1) under rainfed situation.

b) Raise one row of short or medium duration redgram as inter crop for every four rows of groundnut (4:1) under rainfed as well as irrigated condition.

c) Multistoreyed cropping: For rainfed Vertisols of Virudhunagar, Tirunelveli, Thoothukudi districts recording more than $3 0 0 ~ \mathsf { m m }$ of rainfall during the crop growth period, multistoreyed cropping system Agathi $^ +$ Redgram (Co 5) $^ +$ Cotton (MCU 10) $^ +$ Blackgram (Co 5) is highly profitable. (Agathi in I tier with $_ { 1 \times }$ 1 m spacing - Redgram in II tier with a spacing of $4 5 \times 2 0 ~ \mathsf { c m }$ - Cotton in the III tier with a spacing of $4 5 \times 1 5 ~ \mathrm { c m }$ - Blackgram in the IV tier with the spacing of $3 0 \times 1 0 ~ \mathrm { c m } )$ ). For rainfed Vertisols receiving less than $3 0 0 \mathsf { m m }$ of rainfall, Agathi $^ +$ Sorghum $( \mathsf { C O } 2 6 ) +$ Cotton (MCU 10) $^ +$ Blackgram (Co 5) system is ideal. (Agathi in I tier with a spacing of 1 x 1 m - sorghum in II tier with a spacing of $4 5 \times 1 5$ cm - cotton in III tier with the spacing of $4 5 \times 1 5 ~ \mathrm { c m }$ and Blackgram in IV tier with $3 0 \times 1 0 ~ \mathsf { c m } _ { \iota }$ ). For both systems, apply $4 0 \ \mathsf { k g } \ \mathsf { N }$ and 20 $\mathsf { k g } \mathsf { P O } / \mathsf { h a } . 2 \mathsf { 5 }$

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "11. REDGRAM TRANSPLANTING" in the guide.
response:
Select only long duration redgram varieties   
Transplant within the month of August either under rainfed condition or under irrigated condition   
Select poly bag with a size of 6x4 inches and 200 micron thickness   
Fill the poly bag with native soil: Sand: FYM $@ 1 : 1 : 1$ and put 3-4 holes in the bottom to avoid water stagnation   
Soak the seeds in $0 . 2 \%$ Calcium chloride for one hour and dry it under shade for 7 hours to harden the seeds   
Treat the hardened seeds with T. viride $@ 4 \mathsf { g } / \mathsf { k g }$ and ${ 1 0 0 } { \mathsf { g } }$ Rhizobium and ${ 1 0 0 } { \mathsf { g } }$ phosphobacterium. Sow the seeds $@ 2$ /poly bag at 1 cm depth   
Sow the seeds in polybags 30-45 days prior to transplanting   
Plough the field deeply to get fine tilth followed by 2-3 harrowings at 3 weeks prior to transplanting   
In medium to deep soils for raising long duration varieties, dig 15 sqcm pits at ${ \sf 5 ^ { \prime } }$ $\textsf { X } 3 ^ { \prime }$ for pure crops and $6 ^ { \prime } \times 3 ^ { \prime }$ for intercropping under irrigated condition. In rainfed condition dig the pits at a spacing of $5 ^ { \prime } { \times } 3 ^ { \prime }$ . For short duration varieties dig 15 sq cm pits at $3 ^ { \prime } \times 2 ^ { \prime }$ spacing.   
Under water logging condition, form furrows before digging pits   
Apply inorganic fertilizers @ 25:50:25 kg NPK /ha at 20-30 days after planting as urea, DAP and potash around the seedlings   
Apply $Z n S O _ { 4 } \textcircled { \omega } 2 5 \mathrm { k g / }$ ha as basal along with FYM or sand Nip (removal of top 5 cm) the plants at 20 – 30 days after planting to arrest the terminal growth   
Foliar Spray of Napthalene aceptic acid (NAA) $\textcircled { \omega } \ 0 . 5 \ \mathrm { m } |$ /litre to control flower dropping in red gram.

instruction: From the guide section "12. NUTRITIONAL DISORDERS", extract the content verbatim.
response:
Redgram / Greengram/Blackgram/Cowpea

Zinc: Symptom appears within a month of sowing. The plants are stripped with yellow or pale green foliage. Veins and mid ribs of the leaves are green although tissue around them becomes yellow and bronzed.

Iron: Reduced concentration of Chlorophyll in leaves - pale leaf colour may be indistinguishable from deficiency of nitrogen or other elements.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "PERENNIAL REDGRAM" from the guide.

BSR 1 ender beans are pinkish green in colour and can be ooked as curry or added to Kurma or Sabji. When the
beansmature they can be used as Dhal. Recommended for growing in kitchen gardens, backyards, farm road sides, as border crop in sugarcane, banana and betelvine and as a shade crop in turmeric and as a bund crop in paddy double cropped wetlands.
SeasonJune – July Height of the plant: 150 - 200 cm Number of branches 7 - 10
FloweringFive months from date of sowing
Pit SizeSmall pits are dug 90 cm apart and the pits are filled with a mixture of well decomposed manure or compost and soil.
Fertilizer applicationUrea 15 g and superphosphate 30 g / pit.
Planting methodsTwo to three seeds are dibbled per pit and watered. When they grow six inches height one plant may be retained in each pit.
IrrigationNeed based
Harvestingrequired.If harvested when the pods are tender the beans will be fit for making curry. Each plant will yield two to three kg of green pods at an average seed yield of 750 g to one kg per plant. After the first harvest the branches are pruned and allowed to grow further. instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "1. FIELD PREPARATION" from the guide.
response:
i. Prepare the land to fine tilth and form beds and channels.   
ii. Amendments for soil surface crusting: To tide over the soil surface crusting apply lime at the rate of 2t /ha along with FYM at $1 2 . 5 ~ \mathrm { t } / \mathsf { h a }$ or composted coirpith at 12.5 t/ha to get an additional yield of about $1 5 - 2 0 \%$ .

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "2. SEED TREATMENT" in the guide.
response:
Treat the seeds with Carbendazim or Thiram $\textcircled { \omega } 2 \ g / \kappa \mathrm { g }$ of seed 24 hours before sowing (or) with talc formulation of Trichoderma viride $\textcircled { \omega } \ 4 \mathrm { g } / \kappa \mathrm { g }$ of seed (or) Pseudomonas fluorescens $\textcircled { \alpha } 1 0 \ g / \kappa \ g \ \varsigma { \bf e }$ ed. Bio control agents are compatible with biofertilizers. First treat the seeds with Biocontrol agents and then with Rhizobium. Fungicides and biocontrol agents are incompatible.

Note: Seed treatment will protect the seedlings from seed borne pathogens, root-rot and seedlings diseases.

instruction: From the guide section "3. SEED TREATMENT WITH BIOFERTILIZER", extract the content verbatim.
response:
a) Treat the seeds required for sowing 1 ha with $2 0 0 { \mathsf { g } }$ each of Rhizobial culture COG 15, Phosphobacteria and PGPR (Pseudomonas sp.) using rice gruel, shade dry it before sowing. (or) Treat one hectare of seeds with $2 5 \ \mathsf { g }$ each of each of powder formulation of Rhizobium and AM fungi using binder (polymer), shade dry before sowing.

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "7. FOLIAR APPLICATION" in the guide.
response:
a. Foliar spray of NAA $4 0 \ m \mathbf { g } ,$ /litre once at pre-flowering and another at 15 days thereafterto reduce flower shedding.

c. Foliar spray of salicylic acid $1 0 0 \mathsf { m } \mathsf { g } ,$ /litre once at preflowering and another at 15 days there after to improve translocation efficiency and seed yield.

response:
i) Pre emergence application of Pendimethalin 1.0 litres/ha under irrigated condition, PE application of Pendimethalin 0.75 litres/ha under rainfed condition on 3 days after sowing using Backpack/ Knapsack/Rocker sprayer fitted with flat fan nozzle using 500 litres of water for spraying one ha followed by one hand weeding at 20 DAS (or) EPOE application of quizalofop ethyl $\textcircled { \alpha } 5 0 \ g \mathsf { a i } / \mathsf { h a } ^ { - 1 }$ and imazethapyr $@$ $5 0 ~ \mathsf { g }$ ai ha-1 on 15 – 20 DAS. If herbicides are not applied give two hand weedings on 15 and 30 days after sowing.

ii) Apply PE Pendimethalin $30 \%$ EC $^ +$ Imazethapyr $2 \%$ EC (Valor $32 \%$ EC; Readymix herbicide) $@ 1 . 0 \mathsf { k g }$ a.i. ha-1 at 3 DAS.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "9. Multi bloom technology" from the guide.
response:
A special technology being practiced in Pattukottai block of Tanjore district for blackgram and greengram. The soil is alluvial and rich in organic matter and nutrients. The crop is sown during early summer (Jan.-Feb.) as normal crop and fertilizer is applied as per the recommendation for irrigated crop. In addition to that, top dressing of Nitrogen is done with an extra dose of 25 to $3 0 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ through urea. Since pulses are indeterminate growth habit and continue to produce new flashes, the top dressing will be done on 40-45 days after sowing. The crops complete its first flesh of matured pods during $6 0 \cdot 6 5 ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ day, further their second new flesh within 20-25 days. Therefore two fleshes of pods can be harvested at a time within the duration of 100 days. CROP PROTECTION A. Pest management Economic threshold level for important pests
PestETL

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "Harvest" in the guide.
response:
Harvest the pods 30 days after 50 per cent flowering. At this stage, the colour of majority of the pods $(80 \% )$ will be black. The pod moisture content will be around $1 7 - 1 8 \%$ .   
Harvest the pods as pickings, if the flowering period is longer.   
Dry the pods to 13 to 15 per cent moisture content.

instruction: From the guide section "Storage", extract the content verbatim.
response:
Store the seeds with a seed moisture content of $10 \mathrm { ~ - ~ } 1 2 \mathrm { ~ \% ~ }$ in gunny or cloth bags for short term storage (8 - 9 months).   
• Store the seeds with a seed moisture content of $8 \%$ in polylined gunny bag for medium term storage (12 - 15 months).   
• Store the seeds with a seed moisture content less than $8 \%$ in 700 gauge polythene bag for long term storage (more than15 months).

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "7. FOLIAR APPLICATION" in the guide.
response:
a. Foliar spray of NAA $4 0 \ m \ g _ { i }$ /litre and Salicylic acid $1 0 0 \mathrm { ~ m g } /$ /litre once at preflowering and another at 15 days thereafter to reduce flower shedding.

instruction: From the guide section "8. WEED MANAGEMENT", extract the content verbatim.
response:
i) Pre emergence application of Pendimethalin $@ 1 . 0$ litres / ha under irrigated condition or PE application of Pendimethalin 0.75 litres per hectare under rainfed condition on 3 days after sowing using Backpack/ Knapsack/Rocker sprayer fitted with flat fan nozzle using 500 litres of water for spraying one ha. After this, one hand weeding on ${ 3 0 } ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ days after sowing gives weed free environment throughout the crop period (or) EPOE application of quizalofop ethyl $\textcircled { \alpha } 5 0 \mathrm { \ g } \mathrm { a i } / \mathrm { h } \mathrm { a } ^ { - 1 }$ and imazethapyr $@ 5 0 \{ $ ai ${ \mathsf { h } } { \mathsf { a } } ^ { - 1 }$ on 15 – 20 DAS.   
ii) If herbicide is not applied give two hand weedings on 15 and 30 days after sowing.   
iii) Apply PE Pendimethalin $30 \%$ EC $^ +$ Imazethapyr $2 \%$ EC (Valor $32 \%$ EC; Readymix herbicide) $@ 1 . 0 \mathsf { k g }$ a.i. $\mathsf { h } \mathsf { a } ^ { - 1 }$ at 3 DAS.   
iv) For the irrigated blackgram PE isoproturon $\textcircled { \omega } 0 . 5 ~ \mathsf { k g } ~ \mathsf { h a } ^ { - 1 }$ followed by one hand weeding on 30 DAS.

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "Pre-sowing seed treatment" in the guide.
response:
Remove all discoloured seeds and use only normal coloured seeds (olive green) for seed purpose.   
• Avoid bruchid infested seeds for sowing.   
• If the presence of hard seed percentage exceeds more than $10 \%$ , scarify the seeds with commercial ${ \sf H } _ { 2 } { \sf S } { \sf O } _ { 4 }$ for 2 min.   
• Harden the greengram seeds for garden and dry land ecosystem with 100 ppm $\mathsf { M n S O _ { 4 } }$ for $^ \textrm { \scriptsize 3 h }$ at the ratio of 1:0.3 ratio and dry back to original seed moisture content $( 8 - 9 \% )$ under shade.

instruction: According to the section "Pre-sowing seed treatment", what information is provided? Quote it.
response:
Remove all discoloured seeds and use only normal coloured seeds (olive green) for seed purpose.
• Avoid bruchid infested seeds for sowing.
• If the presence of hard seed percentage exceeds more than $10 \%$ , scarify the seeds with commercial ${ \sf H } _ { 2 } { \sf S } { \sf O } _ { 4 }$ for 2 min.
• Harden the greengram seeds for garden and dry land ecosystem with 100 ppm $\mathsf { M n S O _ { 4 } }$ for $^ \textrm { \scriptsize 3 h }$ at the ratio of 1:0.3 ratio and dry back to original seed moisture content $( 8 - 9 \% )$ under shade.

Cowpea is called the "hungry - season crop" because it is the first crop to be harvested before the cereal crops. Cowpea is tolerant of shading and can be combined with tall cereal plants such as sorghum and maize. It is sensitive to waterlogging, though less than other legumes. High moisture may hinder cowpea crops in the sub - humid tropics due to the many diseases. Frost can damage the plant during flowering period.

instruction: From the guide section "2. SEED TREATMENT", extract the content verbatim.
response:
Treat the seeds with Carbendazim or Thiram $2 ~ \mathrm { g } / \ k \mathrm { g }$ of seed 24 hours before sowing (or) with talc formulation of Trichoderma viride $@ 4 \mathsf { g } / \mathsf { k g }$ of seed (or) Pseudomonas fluorescens $\textcircled { \omega } 1 0 \mathrm { g } / \mathrm { k g } \mathrm { s e e d }$ .

Biocontrol agents are compatible with biofertilizers.   
First treat the seeds with biocontrol agents and then with Rhizobium.   
Fungicides and biocontrol agents are incompatible.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "3. SEED TREATMENT WITH BIOFERTILIZER" from the guide.
response:
a) Fungicide-treated seeds, should be again treated with a bacterial culture. There should be an interval of atleast 24 hours between fungicidal and biofertilizer treatments.   
b) The improved rhizobial strain COC 10 is more effective in increasing the yield. Treat the seeds with one packet $( 2 0 0 \ \mathrm { g / h a } )$ of Rhizobial culture (COC 10) and one packet $( 2 0 0 \mathrm { g / h a } )$ of Phosphobacteria developed at TNAU using rice kanji as binder. If the seed treatment is not carried out apply 10 packets $( 2 \ \mathrm { \ k g / h a } )$ of Phosphobacteria with 25 kg of FYM and $2 5 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ of soil before sowing. Dry the biofertilizer treated seeds in shade for 15 minutes before sowing.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "Intercultural operation" from the guide.
response:
Clip the tendrils for promotion of flower production.   
Up root and destroy the plants exhibiting severe symptoms of mosaic in the early stages of growth.

Spray $2 \%$ DAP at flower initiation and at peak flowering to promote pod setting.

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT FOR PULSE PESTS" in the guide.
response:
1. Stem fly

It attacks blackgram, greengram and cowpea. Adult fly is blackish and lay eggs on the young leaves • Affected plants get dried • Immature stage will be inside the stem Economic threshold level is $10 \%$ damage

2. Aphids

Attacks blackgram, greengram, lab lab, cowpea and redgram. Congregated on the growing shoots, leaves, flowers and pods. • Affected plants will be weak and stunted Because of honeydew ant movements will be there

3. Whiteflies

• Attacks blackgram, greengram, cowpea and soyabean • Act as vector for yellow mosaic virus disease

4. Bugs • Desap the flowers and pods • Affected pods show shriveled grains

5. Pod borers

Gram pod borer, spotted pod borer, blue butterflies, pod fly and blister beetles are the major borers • Blister beetles feed on flower buds, flowers and young pods • Spotted pod borers web the flowers and young pods Gram pod borer, plume moth and blue butterflies bore into the pods • Pod fly feed on the seeds of redgram.

IPM

Take up the sowing of blackgram from September to November with increased seed rate $( 2 5 \mathrm { k g / h a } )$ in stem fly endemic areas.   
Remove alternate hosts   
Use of pheromone traps $@$ 12/ha for Gram pod borer   
Spray insecticides like methyl demeton or dimethoate or monocrotophos $@$ 500ml/ha to reduce the sucking insects   
Spray Neem seed kernel extract $( 2 5 \mathrm { k g / h a } )$ against pod borers   
Avoid insecticidal spray when parasitoids and predators activity is high.

6. Storage pests

Dry the seeds adequately to reduce moisture level to $10 \%$ .   
Use pitfall traps or two in one model trap to assess the time of emergence of field carried over pulse beetle in storage and accordingly sun-dry the produce.   
Seed: Mix any one of the following for every $100 k g$ : Activated kaolin 1 kg Malathion 5 D 1 kg TNAU Neem oil 60 EC (C) 1lit. Pungam oil   
1lit.   
Monocrotophos 36 SL $4 0 0 \mathsf { m } \mathsf { l }$   
Pack in polythene lined gunny bags for storage

instruction: From the guide section "1. FIELD PREPARATION", extract the content verbatim.
response:
i) Plough with tractor using a disc followed by harrow, once or twice with iron plough or 3 - 4 times with country plough till all the clods are broken and a fine tilth is obtained.

ii) Chiselling for soils with hard pan: Chisel the soils having hard pan formation at shallow depth with chisel plough first at $_ { 0 . 5 \textrm { m } }$ interval in one direction and then in the direction perpendicular to the previous one, once in three years. Apply 12.5 t/ha of FYM or composted coir pith besides chiselling.

iii) Amendments for soil surface crusting: a) To tide over the surface crusting, apply lime $\textcircled { \scriptsize { \alpha } } 2 \mathrm { t } / \mathrm { h } \mathsf { a }$ along with FYM or composted coir pith $\textcircled { \omega } 1 2 . 5 ~ \mathrm { t / h a } .$ b) Coir pith at $1 2 . 5 \ : \mathrm { t } / \mathsf { h a }$ converted to compost by inoculating with Pleurotus and applied serves as a good source of nutrients.

instruction: What does the guide state under the heading "1. FIELD PREPARATION"? Quote the text.
response: i) Plough with tractor using a disc followed by harrow, once or twice with iron plough or 3 - 4 times with country plough till all the clods are broken and a fine tilth is obtained.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "2. APPLICATION OF FERTILIZERS" from the guide.
response:
Apply NPK fertilizers as per soil test recommendation. If soil test is not done, follow the blanket recommendation.

For rainfed groundnut –castor intercropping system, apply the recommended dose of $1 0 { : } 1 0 { : } 4 5 \mathrm { ~ k g \ N P K \ h a ^ { - 1 } }$ to the main crop of groundnut and for castor apply the recommended dose of $4 0 \ k g \ N$

Soil test crop response based integrated plant nutrition system (STCR- IPNS) recommendation may be adopted for prescribing fertilizer doses for specified yield targets. (ready reckoners are furnished )

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "5. NUTRITIONAL DISORDER" in the guide.
response:
Zinc deficiency: Apply $2 5 ~ \mathsf { k g } ~ \mathsf { Z n S O } _ { 4 } / \mathsf { h a } ~$ as basal.   
If soil analysis shows less than 1.2 ppm of zinc, soil application of $2 5 \mathsf { k g } \mathsf { Z n S O } _ { 4 }$ is recommended. Reduce $Z n S O _ { 4 }$ application from $2 5 . 0 \mathsf { k g } \mathsf { h } \mathsf { a } ^ { - 1 }$ to $1 2 . 5 \mathsf { k g } \mathsf { h a } ^ { - 1 }$ if FYM is applied $\textcircled { \omega } 1 2 . 5 \mathrm { t } \mathsf { h } \mathsf { a } ^ { - 1 }$ . For the standing crop, less than 39.4 ppm of zinc in leaves, foliar spray of $0 . 5 \% 2 \mathsf { n S o } _ { 4 }$ is recommended.   
Iron deficiency: Foliar of spray $1 \% \mathsf { F e S O } _ { 4 } + 0 . 1 \%$ citric acid thrice on 30, 40 and 50 days after sowing.   
Boron deficiency: Application of Borax $1 0 ~ \mathsf { k g }$   
Sulphur deficiency: Gypsum 400 kg/ha as soil application at $4 5 ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ day after sowing.

Use $1 2 0 ~ \mathsf { k g / h a }$ of kernels, 175 kg/ha of kernels for bold seeded varieties.

instruction: According to the section "5. NUTRITIONAL DISORDER", what information is provided? Quote it.
response:
Zinc deficiency: Apply $2 5 ~ \mathsf { k g } ~ \mathsf { Z n S O } _ { 4 } / \mathsf { h a } ~$ as basal.
If soil analysis shows less than 1.2 ppm of zinc, soil application of $2 5 \mathsf { k g } \mathsf { Z n S O } _ { 4 }$ is recommended. Reduce $Z n S O _ { 4 }$ application from $2 5 . 0 \mathsf { k g } \mathsf { h } \mathsf { a } ^ { - 1 }$ to $1 2 . 5 \mathsf { k g } \mathsf { h a } ^ { - 1 }$ if FYM is applied $\textcircled { \omega } 1 2 . 5 \mathrm { t } \mathsf { h } \mathsf { a } ^ { - 1 }$ . For the standing crop, less than 39.4 ppm of zinc in leaves, foliar spray of $0 . 5 \% 2 \mathsf { n S o } _ { 4 }$ is recommended.
Iron deficiency: Foliar of spray $1 \% \mathsf { F e S O } _ { 4 } + 0 . 1 \%$ citric acid thrice on 30, 40 and 50 days after sowing.
Boron deficiency: Application of Borax $1 0 ~ \mathsf { k g }$
Sulphur deficiency: Gypsum 400 kg/ha as soil application at $4 5 ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ day after sowing.

instruction: From the guide section "8. SEED TREATMENT", extract the content verbatim.
response:
i) Treat the seeds with talc formulation of Trichoderma viride @ 4 g/kg seed or Pseudomonas fluorescens $\textcircled { \omega } 1 0 \mathrm { g } / \mathrm { k g } \mathrm { s e e d }$ . Biocontrol agents are compatible with biofertilizers. Treat the seeds with biocontrol agents first and then with Rhizobium. Fungicides and biocontrol agents are incompatible.   
ii) Treat the seeds with Trichoderma $@ 4 \mathbf { g } / \mathsf { k g }$ . This can be done just before sowing. It is compatible with biofertilizers. SUCH SEEDS SHOULD NOT BE TREATED WITH FUNGICIDES (or)   
iii) Treat the seeds with Thiram or Mancozeb $\textcircled { \textsf { o } } 4 \ \& / \kappa \{ \mathsf { g } $ of seed or Carboxin o Carbendazim at $2 ~ \mathrm { g } / \ k \mathrm { g }$ of seed.   
iv) Treat one hectare of seeds with ${ 1 2 5 \mathrm { ~ m } } |$ of Rhizobium (TNAU 14) and ${ 1 2 5 \mathrm { ~ m } } |$ Phosphobacteria, shade dry it for 30 minutes before sowing

9. SOWING

• Use Kovai seed drill/gorru to sow the seeds in lines.   
• Put one seed in each hole. Protect the seeds from crows and squirrels.

instruction: What does the guide state under the heading "8. SEED TREATMENT"? Quote the text.
response:
i) Treat the seeds with talc formulation of Trichoderma viride @ 4 g/kg seed or Pseudomonas fluorescens $\textcircled { \omega } 1 0 \mathrm { g } / \mathrm { k g } \mathrm { s e e d }$ . Biocontrol agents are compatible with biofertilizers. Treat the seeds with biocontrol agents first and then with Rhizobium. Fungicides and biocontrol agents are incompatible.
ii) Treat the seeds with Trichoderma $@ 4 \mathbf { g } / \mathsf { k g }$ . This can be done just before sowing. It is compatible with biofertilizers. SUCH SEEDS SHOULD NOT BE TREATED WITH FUNGICIDES (or)
iii) Treat the seeds with Thiram or Mancozeb $\textcircled { \textsf { o } } 4 \ \& / \kappa \{ \mathsf { g } $ of seed or Carboxin o Carbendazim at $2 ~ \mathrm { g } / \ k \mathrm { g }$ of seed.
iv) Treat one hectare of seeds with ${ 1 2 5 \mathrm { ~ m } } |$ of Rhizobium (TNAU 14) and ${ 1 2 5 \mathrm { ~ m } } |$ Phosphobacteria, shade dry it for 30 minutes before sowing

instruction: List the bullet or numbered items that appear under the heading "8. SEED TREATMENT".
response: 9. SOWING

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "10. INTERCROPPING" from the guide.
response:
i) Raise one row of cowpea for every five rows of groundnut wherever red hairy caterpillar is endemic.   
ii) Raise intercrops like redgram, blackgram, sunflower, gingelly or other pulses.   
iii) Cumbu can be raised as intercrop.   
iv) Groundnut $^ +$ Gingelly or Groundnut $^ +$ Blackgram in the ratio of 4:1 or Groundnut $^ +$ Cowpea at 6:1 ratio and Groundnut $^ +$ Sunflower at 6:2 ratio may be raised.

11. WEED MANAGEMENT

i) Pre-emergence: Pendimethalin $@ 1 . 0$ litre/ha applied through flat fan nozzle with 500 l of water/ha. After 35 - 40 days one hand weeding may be given.   
ii) If no herbicide is applied two hand weeding may be given on $2 0 ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ and $4 0 ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ day after sowing.

instruction: According to the section "10. INTERCROPPING", what information is provided? Quote it.
response:
i) Raise one row of cowpea for every five rows of groundnut wherever red hairy caterpillar is endemic.
ii) Raise intercrops like redgram, blackgram, sunflower, gingelly or other pulses.
iii) Cumbu can be raised as intercrop.
iv) Groundnut $^ +$ Gingelly or Groundnut $^ +$ Blackgram in the ratio of 4:1 or Groundnut $^ +$ Cowpea at 6:1 ratio and Groundnut $^ +$ Sunflower at 6:2 ratio may be raised.

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "12. EARTHING UP" in the guide.
response:
Accomplish earthing up during second hand weeding/late hand weeding (in herbicide application).

NOTE: i) Earthing up provides medium for the peg development ii) Use the improved hoe with long handle which can be worked more efficiently in a standing position. iii) Do not disturb the soil after $4 5 ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ day of sowing as it will affect pod formation adversely.

instruction: From the guide section "13. APPLICATION OF CALCIUM SULPHATE (GYPSUM)", extract the content verbatim.
response:
i) Apply gypsum $\textcircled { \alpha } \ 4 0 0 \ \textcircled { \times } \ \textcircled { \mathrm { h a } }$ by the side of the plants on 40th to 70th day depending upon soil moisture.   
ii) Apply gypsum, hoe and incorporate it in the soil and then earth up.   
iii) Avoid gypsum in calciferous soils.   
iv) Gypsum is effective in soils deficient in calcium and sulphur.

NOTE: Application of gypsum encourages pod formation and better filling up of the pods.

Application of gypsum at the rate of $50 \%$ basal both in rainfed and irrigated condition reduces Khadhasty malady and pod scab nematode

instruction: According to the section "13. APPLICATION OF CALCIUM SULPHATE (GYPSUM)", what information is provided? Quote it.
response:
i) Apply gypsum $\textcircled { \alpha } \ 4 0 0 \ \textcircled { \times } \ \textcircled { \mathrm { h a } }$ by the side of the plants on 40th to 70th day depending upon soil moisture.
ii) Apply gypsum, hoe and incorporate it in the soil and then earth up.
iii) Avoid gypsum in calciferous soils.
iv) Gypsum is effective in soils deficient in calcium and sulphur.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "14. HARVESTING" from the guide.
response:
i) Observe the crop, considering its average duration. Drying and falling of older leaves and yellowing of the top leaves indicate maturity.   
ii) Pull out a few plants at random and shell the pods. If the inner shell is brownish black and not white, then the crop has matured.   
iii) Irrigate prior to harvest, if the soil is dry, as this will facilitate easy harvesting. If there is enough moisture in the soil, there is no need for irrigation for harvesting.   
iv) If water is not available for irrigating the field prior to harvest, work a mould board plough or work a country plough, so that the plants are uprooted. Engage labour to search pods left out in the soil, if necessary.

NOTE: Do not keep the pulled out plants in heaps when they are wet, especially the bunch varieties, as the pods will start sprouting. v) Strip off the pods from the plants. Groundnut stripper developed by TNAU can be used. vi) Dry the pods in the sun for 4 or 5 days. Repeat drying for 2 or 3 more days after an interval of 2 or 3 days to ensure complete drying. When temperature is very high, avoid direct sun drying. Collect the pods in gunnies and store on the ground over a layer of sand to avoid any moisture coming in contact with dry pods.

I. Irrigated

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "1. FIELD PREPARATION" in the guide.
response:
i) Plough with tractor using a disc followed by harrow, once or twice with iron plough or 3 - 4 times with country plough till all the clods are broken and a fine tilth is obtained.   
ii) Chiselling for soils with hard pan: Chisel the soils having hard pan formation at shallow depth with chisel plough first at $_ { 0 . 5 \textrm { m } }$ interval in one direction and then in the direction perpendicular to the previous one, once in three years. Apply 12.5 t/ha FYM or composted coir pith besides chiselling.   
iii) Amendments for soil surface crusting: a) To tide over the surface crusting, apply lime $\textcircled { \scriptsize { \omega } } 2 \ t / \mathsf { h a }$ along with FYM or composted coir pith $\textcircled { \alpha } 1 2 . 5 ~ \mathrm { t } / \mathrm { h a } . ~ $ b) When coir pith at $1 2 . 5 ~ \mathrm { t / h a }$ is converted into compost by inoculating with Pleurotus and applied, it serves as a good source of nutrien

instruction: From the guide section "2. APPLICATION OF FERTILIZERS", extract the content verbatim.
response:
If soil test is not done, follow the blanket recommendation.

N P K 25 50 75 kg/ha 80 kg S as gypsum on 45 DAS

For calcareous soil, application of $4 0 \ k g \leq$ elemental sulphur along with either $5 0 \mathrm { ~ k g ~ F e S O _ { 4 } + }$ 12.5 t FYM or 5 kg Fe EDTA can be used. For sulphur deficient calcareous soil, application of 60 kg S/ha elemental sulphur as basal application is recommended. Growing CO7, ALR3 and CO2 can be recommended in calcareous soils tolerate lime induced iron chlorosis while CO4, TMV2 and ALG320 were highly sensitive to iron deficiency.

N and K in three splits viz., $50 \%$ N & K as basal $+ 2 5 \%$ N and K at $2 0 \mathsf { D A S } + 2 5 \% \mathsf { N }$ and K at 45 DAS is recommended.

Soil test crop response based integrated plant nutrition system (STCR- IPNS) recommendation may be adopted for prescribing fertilizer doses for specified yield targets. (ready reckoners are furnished )

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "6. NUTRITIONAL DISORDER" from the guide.
response:
Zinc deficiency: Apply $2 5 \mathrm { k g } 2 \mathrm { n s } 0 _ { 4 } / \mathrm { h a }$ as basal.

If soil analysis shows less than 1.2 ppm of zinc, soil application of $2 5 \ \mathsf { k g } \ \mathsf { Z n S o } _ { 4 }$ is recommended. Reduce $Z n S O _ { 4 }$ application from $2 5 . 0 \mathrm { ~ k g } \mathrm { \ h a } ^ { - 1 }$ to $1 2 . 5 ~ \mathsf { k g } \mathsf { h a } ^ { - 1 }$ if FYM is applied $\textcircled { \omega } 1 2 . 5 \mathrm { ~ t ~ h a } ^ { - 1 }$ . For the standing crop, less than 39.4 ppm of zinc in leaves, foliar spray of $0 . 5 \% 2 \mathsf { n S o } _ { 4 }$ is 4 recommended.

Iron deficiency $:$ Foliar spray of $1 \%$ $\mathsf { F e S O } _ { 4 } + 0 . 1 \%$ citric acid on 30, 40 and 50 days after sowing. Apply $5 0 \ k g \ \mathsf { F e S O } _ { 4 } + 1 2 . 5$ t FYM basally.

Boron deficiency: Application of Borax $1 0 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ basally (or) $0 . 2 \%$ boric acid twice on 40, 50 DAS.

For multinutrient deficiency: Apply $2 5 \mathrm { k g } \mathrm { Z n } \mathsf { S O } _ { 4 } + 1 0 \mathrm { k g } \mathrm { b o r a x } + 2 0 \mathrm { k g } \mathsf { S } \mathsf { a s }$ Gypsum.

Copper deficiency: Basal application of $1 0 ~ { \mathsf { k g } } \mathsf { C u S O } _ { 4 }$ or $0 . 2 \% \mathsf { C u S O } _ { 4 }$ . Spray twice after observing plant nutrient deficiencies.

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "7. SEED RATE" in the guide.
response:
Use $1 2 5 ~ \mathrm { { k g / h a } }$ of kernels. Increase the seed rate by $1 5 \%$ in the case of bold seeded varieties.

8. SPACING

Adopt a spacing of $3 0 ~ \mathsf { c m }$ between rows and ${ 1 0 \ \mathsf { c m } }$ between plants. Wherever groundnut ring mosaic (bud necrosis) is prevalent, adopt a spacing of 15cm x 15 cm.

instruction: From the guide section "9. SEED TREATMENT", extract the content verbatim.
response:
i) Treat the seeds with Trichoderma viride $ @ ~ 4 ~ \mathsf { g } / \mathsf { k g }$ seed or Pseudomonas fluorescens $@$ $) 1 0 ~ \mathsf { g } / \mathsf { k g }$ seed. Biocontrol agents are compatible with biofertilizers. First treat the seeds with biocontrol agents and then with Rhizobium. Fungicides and biocontrol agents are incompatible.   
ii) Treatment with Trichoderma can be done just before sowing. SUCH SEEDS SHOULD NOT BE TREATED WITH FUNGICIDES. (or)   
iii) Treat the seeds with Thiram or Mancozeb $ @ ~ 4 ~ \mathsf { g } / \mathsf { k g }$ of seed or Carboxin or Carbendazim at $2 ~ \mathrm { g } / \ k \mathrm { g }$ of seed.   
iv) Treat the seeds with 3 packets $( 6 0 0 \mathrm { g } ) / \mathsf { h a }$ of Rhizobial culture TNAU14 developed at TNAU using rice kanji as binder. If the seed treatment is not carried out, apply 10 packets/ha $( 2 0 0 0 \ \mathsf { g } )$ with $2 5 \kappa \mathsfit { g }$ of FYM and $2 5 \kappa \mathsfit { g }$ of soil before sowing.

Seed treatment will protect the young seedlings from root-rot and collar rot infection.

10. SOWING

a) Dibble the seeds at 4 cm depth along with fertilizer.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "14. WATER MANAGEMENT" from the guide.
response:
Schedule the irrigation at 0.40 and 0.60 IW/CPE ratio during vegetative and reproductive phase respectively. Regulate irrigation as per the growth phase of the crop. Pre-flowering phase : 1 to 25 days Flowering phase : 26 to 60 days Maturity phase: 61 to 105 days Regulate irrigation based on physiological growth phases. Pegging, flowering and pod development phases are critical for irrigation during which period adequate soil moisture is essential. Irrigate as follows:

i) Sowing or pre-sowing   
ii) Life irrigation, 4 - 5 days after sowing.   
iii) 20 days after sowing   
iv) At flowering give two irrigations   
v) At pegging stage give one or two irrigations   
vi) In pod development stage, 2 - 3 irrigations depending on the soil type

Note: Spraying $0 . 5 \%$ Potassium chloride during flowering and pod development stages will aid to mitigate the ill effects of water stress. Sprinkler irrigation will save water to the tune of about $30 \%$ . Borderstrip irrigation is recommended in command areas in light textured soils. Composted coir pith increases moisture availability and better drainage in heavy textured soil.

In rain fed crop set up 3 to 4 light traps and bonfires immediately after rains to attract and kill the moths. and cowpea. Collect and destroy egg masses in the cropped
area. Dig a trench 30 cm deep and 25 cm wide with
perpendicular sides around the infested fields to avoid larval migration.
Spray Aa NPV ● Apply quinalphos 1.5 DP 25 kg/ha
pure suspension of virus with the nucleus culture in water. Dip Calotropis leaves in virus suspension, shade dry and feed them to starved larvae for 1 or 2 days. From third day, normal, untreated leaves can be fed to these larvae. From 5t day, the treated larvae wil start dying. Virus infected larvae can be diagnosed by their pinkish ventral surface, their head hanging downwards with white body contents oozing out through ruptured body wall in the late stage. Collect the dying larvae, keep in fresh potable water for a few days, grind the larvae and filter through several layers of fine cloth and collect fitrate (Crude virus suspension). Use virus suspension obtained from 750 medium sized larvae for spraying one hectare along with a sticker 250 ml or Triton in 350 I of water. Use potable water for mixing and spray in the evening hours.

as the early symptoms of lace-like leaves appear on castor, cowpea and groundnut. Spray MethomyI 40 SP 750ml / ha to control the early

instruction: From the guide section "Harvest", extract the content verbatim.
response:
Harvest the pods as and when the colour of the inner side of the shell turns black and dry to 10 - 12 per cent moisture.

#

• Stake the plants as the pods are exposed outside for easy drying of pods.   
• Dry the pods to $1 5 - 2 0 \%$ moisture content under sun.

instruction: According to the section "Harvest", what information is provided? Quote it.
response: Harvest the pods as and when the colour of the inner side of the shell turns black and dry to 10 - 12 per cent moisture.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "Decortication" from the guide.
response:
Dry the pods to 16 per cent moisture content and decorticate either manually or using hand operated decorticator with proper adjustment.   
Dry the kernels to 7 to 8 per cent moisture.   
Practice pod verification based on varietal characteristic before grading to remove genetically impure seeds.   
Remove all discoloured pods.   
Reject mechanically injured pods for seed purpose.

instruction: What does the guide state under the heading "Decortication"? Quote the text.
response:

Remove all discoloured pods.
Reject mechanically injured pods for seed purpose.

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "Seed storage" in the guide.
response:
Store the pods in gunny bags with calcium chloride $\textcircled { \omega } 2 5 0 \mathrm { g } / 3 0 \mathrm { k g }$ of pods.   
• Store the seeds in gunny for short term storage (8 - 9 months) with a seed moisture content of $8 \%$ .   
• Store the seeds in polylined gunny bag for medium term storage (12 - 15 months) with a seed moisture content of $6 \%$ .   
• Store the seeds in 700 gauge polythene bag for long term storage (more than 15 months) with a seed moisture content less than $5 \%$ .

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "1. FIELD PREPARATION" in the guide.
response:
a) Plough the field with tractor twice or with mould board plough thrice or five times with a country plough.   
b) Break the clods in between ploughings and bring the soil to a fine tilth to facilitate quick germination as the seeds are small.   
c) Chiselling for soils with hard pan: Chisel the soils having hard pan formation at shallow depth with chisel plough first at $0 . 5 ~ \mathsf { m }$ interval in one direction and then in the direction perpendicular to the previous one once in three years. Apply 12.5t FYM/composted coir pith besides chiselling.   
d) For irrigated gingelly, form beds of size $1 0 ~ \mathsf { m } ^ { 2 }$ or $2 0 ~ \mathsf { m } ^ { 2 }$ depending upon the availability, inflow of water and slope of the land. Level the beds perfectly without any depressions to prevent water stagnation, which will affect the germination adversely.   
e) In rice fallows, field is ploughed once with optimum moisture, seeds are sown immediately and covered with one more ploughing.

e) In rice fallows, field is ploughed once with optimum moisture, seeds are sown immediately and covered with one more ploughing.

Irrigated: Apply 35:23:23 kg NPK/ha or $2 1 { : } 2 3 { : } 2 3 \mathrm { \ k g \ } \mathsf { N P K } / \mathsf { h a } \mathrm { ~ + ~ } 3$ packets of Azospirillum $( 6 0 0 ~ \mathrm { g / h a } )$ and 3 packets $( 6 0 0 ~ \mathrm { g / h a } )$ of Phosphobacteria or 6 packets of Azophos $( 1 2 0 0 ~ \mathrm { g / h a } )$ (id:)

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "3. APPLICATION OF AZOSPIRILLUM" from the guide.
response:
a) Treat one hectare of seeds with $6 0 0 \ \textrm { g }$ of Azospirillum and $6 0 0 { \mathsf { g } }$ of phosphobacteria (or) $6 0 0 { \mathsf { g } }$ of Azophos. Apply $2 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ of Azospirillum and $2 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ of phosphobacteria (or) $2 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ of Azophos with $2 5 \kappa \mathsfit { g }$ of FYM and $2 5 \kappa \mathsfit { g }$ of sand, mix   
uniformly before sowing as soil application.   
b) Liquid formulation Treat one hectare of seeds with $1 2 5 ~ \mathrm { m l }$ of Azospirillum and ${ 1 2 5 } \mathrm { m } \mathrm { l }$ of Phosphobacteria, shade dry it for 30 minutes before sowing.

4. NUTRITIONAL DISORDERS

a) Manganese deficiency $:$ Leaves develop interveinal chlorosis, chlorotic tissue, later develop light brown or husk coloured necrotic lesions. Mix $1 0 \mathrm { ~ k g } \mathrm { \sf M n S O } _ { 4 }$ /ha with $4 5 \ k \ g$ of soil and broadcost evely in the beds after sowing.   
b) Zinc deficiency: Middle leaves develop chlorosis in the interveinal areas and necrosis along the apical leaf margins. Apply $2 5 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ Zinc sulphate with $4 5 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ of soil and broadcast evenly in the beds after sowing.

Note: Do not incorporate the micronutrient in the soil.

5. SEED RATE

Adopt a seed rate of $5 \ k g / \ h a$

6. SPACING

a) Give a spacing of $3 0 ~ \mathsf { c m }$ between rows and $3 0 ~ \mathsf { c m }$ between plants. b) For rice fallows, seeds are broadcasted and thinned to maintain 11 plants/ $m ^ { 2 }$

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "9. SOWING" in the guide.
response:
a) Sow the seeds preferably in lines.   
b) Mix the seeds with four times its volume of dry sand and drop the mixture evenly along the furrows in which fertilizers are applied.   
c) Sow the seeds to a depth of 3 cm and cover with soil.   
d) The optimum time of sowing for VRI (SV) 1 sesame is second fortnight of February to first fortnight of March under summer irrigated conditions.

instruction: From the guide section "10. WATER MANAGEMENT", extract the content verbatim.
response:
i) Irrigate at sowing and give life irrigation 7 days after sowing depending on the soil and climatic condition and allow excess water to percolate.   
ii) Give one pre-flowering irrigation (25 days): One at flowering and one or two at pod setting. An irrigation at flowering period is critical.

NOTE: The critical stage for moisture requirement is the flowering phase i.e, between 35th to 45th days of sowing. During the maturity phase, moisture status should be low. If more water is given during this phase, maturity of seeds is affected and filling up of the capsules will be poor. Therefore, stop irrigation after 65 days of sowing.

ii) Give one pre-flowering irrigation (25 days): One at flowering and one or two at pod setting. An irrigation at flowering period is critical.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "12. WEED MANAGEMENT" from the guide.
response:
i. Apply, PE application of Pendimethalin 1.0 litre /ha followed by one hand weeding on $2 5 ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ DAS

13. HARVESTING

a) Decide when to harvest i. Observe the crop, considering the average duration of the crop. ii. Twenty five per cent of the leaves from the bottom are shed and the top leaves

loose their colour and turn yellow at maturity. iii. The colour of the stem turns yellow. iv. The colour of the capsules turn yellow upto the middle. v. Harvest before the bottom capsules turn brown. vi. Examine the ${ 1 0 } ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ capsule from the bottom by opening. If the seeds attained the full color of the variety harvest may be taken up. vii. If harvest is delayed/ the capsules will dehisce resulting in yield reduction.

instruction: From the guide section "Storage", extract the content verbatim.
response:
Store the seeds in gunny or cloth bags for short term storage (8 - 9 months) with a seed moisture content of $8 \%$ .   
• Store the seeds in polylined gunny bag for medium term storage (12 - 15 months) with a seed moisture content of $6 - 7 \%$ .   
• Store the seeds in 700 gauge polythene bag for long term storage (more than 15 months) with seed moisture content less than $5 \%$ .

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "CLIMATE REQUIREMENT" from the guide.
response:
T_MaxCT_MinCOptimum cRainfall mmAltitude m MSL
38-4010 - 1520-25350-600up to 2500
Tropical and requires moderately high temperature 20 to $2 7 \mathsf { C }$ with low humidity throughout the growing season. It grows best in areas where there are clear warm sunny days. Prolonged cloudy weather with high temperature at the time of flowering resulted in poor seed setting, which is known as sex reversion. High temperature above $4 1 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { C }$ at flowering time even for as short period results in blasting of flowers. Very resistant to drought but evenly distributed rainfall is required. Heavy rainfall at flowering reduces the yield. Very susceptible to frost but grow even an altitudes of 1200 to $2 1 0 0 ~ \mathsf { m } _ { \cdot }$ , if sown in March- April, perennial varieties are grown at still higher altitude for shade in coffee estates.

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "2. APPLICATION OF FERTILIZERS" in the guide.
response:
Spread 12.5 t/ha of FYM or compost evenly on the main field before last ploughing and incorporate in to soil by working a country plough. Apply 30 kg sulphur/ ha through gypsum at the time of last ploughing for higher castor yield.

NOTE: Do not leave FYM or compost exposed to sunlight as nutrients will be lost.

instruction: Copy the content that appears under the heading "6. PRE TREATMENT OF SEEDS" in the guide.
response:

b) In rainfed situations, seed priming with $1 \%$ KCl for 3 hours and sowing a week before onset of monsoon is recommended.

instruction: From the guide section "12. INTERCROPPING", extract the content verbatim.
response:
Raise one row of castor for every six rows of groundnut. In the case of late receipt of monsoon blackgram $^ +$ castor at 6:1 ratio is recommended. Or Intercropping of castor with Blackgram or Greengram in 1:2 ratio is recommended for rainfed situation.   
Intercropping of castor with small onion in 1:2 ratio by adopting $1 . 5 \ : \mathrm { m } \times 1 . 0 \ : \mathrm { m }$ spacing is recommended for irrigated situation.   
For hilly areas of Tamil Nadu viz., Kalrayan hills, Javadhu hills and Yelagiri hills, Samai (10kg/ha) $^ +$ Castor $1 . 0 ~ \mathrm { { k g / h a } }$ ) $@$ 10:1 ratio-line sowing $( 2 5 \mathsf { c m } \times 1 0 \mathsf { c m } )$ with $50 \%$ organic $( \mathsf { F Y M } \ @ \mathsf { \ 8 . 0 t / h a } )$ ) and $50 \%$ inorganic nutrient $( 2 2 { : } 1 1 \ \mathsf { k g } \ \mathsf { N } \ \& \ \mathsf { P } / \mathsf { h } \mathsf { a } )$ is recommended for realizing maximum profit.

Raise one row of castor for every six rows of groundnut. In the case of late receipt of monsoon blackgram $^ +$ castor at 6:1 ratio is recommended. Or Intercropping of castor with Blackgram or Greengram in 1:2 ratio is recommended for rainfed situation.
Intercropping of castor with small onion in 1:2 ratio by adopting $1 . 5 \ : \mathrm { m } \times 1 . 0 \ : \mathrm { m }$ spacing is recommended for irrigated situation.
For hilly areas of Tamil Nadu viz., Kalrayan hills, Javadhu hills and Yelagiri hills, Samai (10kg/ha) $^ +$ Castor $1 . 0 ~ \mathrm { { k g / h a } }$ ) $@$ 10:1 ratio-line sowing $( 2 5 \mathsf { c m } \times 1 0 \mathsf { c m } )$ with $50 \%$ organic $( \mathsf { F Y M } \ @ \mathsf { \ 8 . 0 t / h a } )$ ) and $50 \%$ inorganic nutrient $( 2 2 { : } 1 1 \ \mathsf { k g } \ \mathsf { N } \ \& \ \mathsf { P } / \mathsf { h } \mathsf { a } )$ is recommended for realizing maximum profit.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "13. HARVESTING THE CROP" from the guide.
response:
Observe the crop considering the average duration of the variety. i) One or more capsules show sign of drying. ii) Cut the matured racemes without damaging the secondaries. iii) Dry the capsule in the sun without heaping it in the shade. iv) Use castor sheller to separate the seeds or beat the dried capsule with wooden planks, winnow and collect the seeds.

For YRCH 1, first harvest has to be done on 90 DAS, subsequently second and third harvest is to be carried out on 120 and 150 DAS, respectively.

For YRCH 2, first harvest has to be done on 110 DAS followed by second and third harvest is to be taken on 140 and 170 DAS, respectively.

The harvested spike should be sun dried and dried capsules can be shelled in the sheller.

instruction: Extract the full text under the heading "3. APPLICATION OF MICRONUTRIENTS" from the guide.
response:
a) Mix $1 2 . 5 ~ \mathsf { k g } / \mathsf { h a }$ of micronutrient mixture formulated by the Department of Agriculture, Tamil Nadu with enough sand to make total quantity of $5 0 ~ \mathsf { k g / h a }$ . For rainfed sunflower apply TNAU MN mixture $@ 7 . 5 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ ha -1 as enriched FYM

b) variety and $1 0 ~ \mathsf { k g } ~ \mathsf { h a } ^ { - 1 }$ as enriched FYM for hybrid and for Irrigated sunflower apply TNAU MN mixture $\textcircled { \omega } 1 2 . 5 ~ \mathsf { k g } ~ \mathsf { h a } ^ { - 1 }$ as enriched FYM for variety and $1 5 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ ${ \mathsf { h } } { \mathsf { a } } ^ { - 1 }$ as enriched FYM for hybrid (Prepare enriched FYM at 1:10 ratio of MN mixture & FYM ; mixat friable moisture &incubate for one month in shade).

c) Apply the mixture over the furrows and top two thirds of the ridges before sowing.

d) Do not incorporate the mixture in the soil.

(i) To overcome manganese deficiency foliar spray of $0 . 5 \%$ MnSO4 on 30,40 & $5 0 ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ day after sowing and   
(ii) For zinc deficiency apply $2 5 ~ \mathsf { k g } ~ \mathsf { Z n s o } _ { 4 } / \mathsf { h a }$ as basal or $0 . 5 \%$ ZnSO4. Spray on $3 0 , 4 0 \& 5 0 ^ { \mathrm { t h } }$ day after sowing.   
(iii) For B and S deficient soils, apply $1 0 ~ \mathsf { k g }$ Borax or $0 . 2 \%$ boric acid twic and 40 kg S as Gypsum/ha.
